abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sumatra basic Education
            Project in Indonesia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: 1) During the financial crisis, dropout rates are
            often low in primary school and transition to junior
            secondary school is the most important attrition point in
            the system, particularly for the poor; 2) During times of
            financial crisis, or political change, projects should be
            designed with a view toward maximum flexibility, and the
            potential for rapid restructuring as the need arises; 3)
            Within the framework of decentralization, the central
            government (MONE) has a role in targeting strategies to
            address the education needs of the poorest communities if
            national goals for basic education are to be achieved; 4)
            School rehabilitation using community participation method
            costs an average of 25 percent less than the contractor
            method, with at least similar quality; 5) While schools are
            generally able to manage the block grant to purchase
            learning input and materials, more assistance is required to
            prepare them in organizing training; 6) Monitoring and
            Evaluation Framework should be agreed during project
            preparation which includes establishing the baseline data,
            capacity building for district and province monitoring staff
            and allocating sufficient resources for monitoring visits to
            project beneficiaries; 7) School mapping can be useful to
            education agencies at all levels; 8) The establishment of a
            strongly staffed, and well managed central project
            coordination unit (CPCU) must be considered a key
            contributing factor to the successful implementation of any
            project with widely disbursed operations; 9) Project
            personnel from provincial and district agencies should
            become more familiar with Bank guidelines and documentation
            requirements; 10) When a project has widely disbursed
            project sites, local administrators, coordinators and
            teachers should be more fully briefed regarding the
            advantages of participating in the project as well as their
            responsibilities; and 11) Improving learning outcomes is a
            complex task and it is best planned with the input from
            local principals and teachers.
